title: Lee Carroll’s Ethos Jazz Quartet
brief_description: Ethos is Lee Carroll's new jazz quartet with Tripp Bratton on drums, Thomas Usher on upright and electric bass, and featuring Jonathan Barrett on alto and tenor sax
description:
Ethos is Lee Carroll's new jazz quartet with Tripp Bratton on drums, Thomas Usher on upright and electric bass, and featuring Jonathan Barrett on alto and tenor sax. 


Super high energy, funky and danceable, Ethos kicks serious....well, you know.

title: The League: Members Exhibition Opening Reception
brief_description: This three-part exhibition presents a history of the Lexington Art League through the artworks of Early Members (1957-1983), Decades Work by artists involved in LAL for over ten years, who will be showing two works separated by a decade of time, and Current Members’ recent artworks.​ The exhibit will also include a vast amount of historical documents from the Lexington Art League, including publications, photographs, members catalogues, and other interesting memorabilia.
description:
From its inception in 1957, the Lexington Art League has existed as a community-based arts organization to support and celebrate visual artists within and surrounding Lexington, Ky. Members of the organization include artists and patrons near and far, businesses and nonprofit organizations, private and institutional partners, staff and board members. Together, we collaborate and support one another in hopes to enrich our personal and cultural creative growth.


This three-part exhibition presents a history of the Lexington Art League through the artworks of Early Members (1957-1983), Decades Work by artists involved in LAL for over ten years, who will be showing two works separated by a decade of time, and Current Members’ recent artworks.​ The exhibit will also include a vast amount of historical documents from the Lexington Art League, including publications, photographs, members catalogues, and other interesting memorabilia. 


Early Members - Artworks by members active between 1957-1983:

Lillian Boyer, Harold Collins, Dalphna Donnelly, Robert James Foose, Elsie Harris, Marie Hochstrasser, Carol Resser, Neil Sulier, Connie Tucker, John Tuska, and Miriam Woolfolk


Decades Work - Pairing of artworks (one recent and one from appx. ten years ago) by members of ten years or more:

Don Ament, Blake Eames, Liz Foley, Jack Girard, Daniel Graham, David C. Hufford, Margee Koffler, Mary Rezny, Hunter Stamps, Helene Steene, and Clay Wainscott


Current Members - Single artworks by current members who have participated with LAL between 1984 and 2018:

Sara Willa Arthur-Paratley, Martin Beck, Ashley Rainwater Bilbro, Adrienne Dixon, Jamie Donaldson, Susan Goldstein, Melissa Hall, Robert C Henrickson, Tina Hixon, Honora Jacob, Cynthia Kelly, Diane Kline, Robert Lackney, Andrew Light, Jo Mackby, Brian Manke, Brooklynn Messer, Claudia Michler, David Mohallatee, Teresa Montejo, Trish Prewitt, Keith Ross, Benjamin Salley, Barbara Steinrock, and Nick Warner


Opening Reception: September 14th, 6-9pm

Free Admission


Free gallery hours during exhibition (September 14-October 14) 

Tue-Thurs 10a-4p

Friday 10a-8p

Sat-Sun 1-4p

title: Rose Thomas Bannister // Keenan Lawler // Concetta Abbate
venues: The James Eads How Memorial Cinema
brief_description: The James Eads How Memorial Cinema is pleased to welcome back Rose Thomas Bannister and friends
description:
The James Eads How Memorial Cinema is pleased to welcome back Rose Thomas Bannister and friends! 


Doors at 7pm. Show at 8pm. 

We'll have a few punches and some snacks. Feel free to bring your own beverages and snacks of choice! 


ROSE THOMAS BANNISTER & THE FILTHY UNBELIEVERS

https://rosethomasbannister.bandcamp.com/

New York Music Daily describes Rose Thomas Bannister as “a nimble guitarist, a gripping storyteller, clever lyricist and a strong, dynamic singer with a direct, clear, matter-of-fact voice” and as “one of the most individualistic and interesting songwriters in any style of music.” Raised in Nebraska, where she founded the Clawfoot House venue, Bannister settled in Brooklyn a few years ago after completing a 63 date DIY tour of the whole United States. She is touring this fall with her band, The Filthy Unbelievers, in support of her new EP “Ambition,” a song cycle based on Macbeth. 


R. KEENAN LAWLER

https://soundcloud.com/r-keenan-lawler

is a Louisville, Kentucky based multi-instrumentalist, improviser, composer, and sound artist. For nearly four decades he has been a restless explorer of sound, and maker of music that literally and figuratively falls between the cracks. From a crash course of learning the guitar in the post-punk era to live sampling performances and generative sound installations concerning concepts of spatiality and hypnagogia. Since the late nineties, he is best known for developing a highly idiosyncratic language on the metal bodied resonator guitar, extending its timbral and harmonic range far outside the usual role in bluegrass or blues.


CONCETTA ABBATE

https://www.concettaabbate.com/

'Like many violinists, Concetta Abbate is classically trained, just as likely to be found playing Ravel or Paganini as she is her own music. She finds inspiration in poetry, literature and scientific observation. The point of the “pocket-sized songs” on her loosely thematic new debut album, Falling in Time (streaming at Bandcamp) is that despite how distracted we are by the demands of dayjobs, family and (yuck) technology and social media, we mustn’t cut ourselves off from the world around us because it’s so interesting.... Abbate finds meaning and beauty in the seemingly mundane, translating that tersely and imagistically into a series of brief, often barely two-minute songs that could be called chamber pop or art-rock but really defy categorization.' --Lucid Culture

title: WRFL DisOrientation Fall 2018
brief_description: If you’d like to get involved by becoming a DJ or figuring out about our other volunteering opportunities, there’s no better time to do it than our DisOrientation
description: Here at WRFL, we enjoy making noise. From jazz to rock and from electronic to Americana, all the stuff you hear on our station is powered by University of Kentucky students and Lexingtonians just like you. If you’d like to get involved by becoming a DJ or figuring out about our other volunteering opportunities, there’s no better time to do it than our DisOrientation. It’s Saturday, September 15th at UK’s Student Center, Room 330AB, and no experience is necessary to attend. For more info, visit WRFL.fm.

title: Homerathon!
brief_description: Homerathon is a read-a-thon of Homer's Odyssey
description: Homerathon is a read-a-thon of Homer's Odyssey. It is a tradition wherever there are lovers of ancient epic poems. Now the tradition has come to Lexingtion! Come and join students from Dr. Murray's Classical Mythology Course as well as UK and Transylvania faculty and students and other members of the Lexington community in reading the oldest and the most exciting adventure story from the ancient Mediterranean world!

title: OTS/Event 204 - Cortex (from Norway) - FREE!
venues: Lucille Caudill Little Fine Arts Library
description:
” No Scandinavian group since Atomic has so powerfully addressed and remade the free jazz of the 60s like Cortex. In a country whose creative music scene is celebrated for its bold hybrids of disparate sounds, Cortex goes another way, embracing tradition in its own unique way, with a personality sketched out by the strength of Johansson’s indelible themes and four distinctive improvisational voices.” .

- Peter Margasak, Chicago Reader 


> OTS / Event 204 <

MONDAY > September 17 


CORTEX (Norway)

Thomas Johansson - trumpet

Kristoffer Berre Alberts - sax

Ola Hayer - bass

Gard Nilssen - drums


@ UK's Niles Gallery (inside the UK Fine Arts Library)

7:30 pm start, all ages welcome, FREE

presented by WRFL 88.1FM


COME OUT, COME OUT!

title: Forum on the Arts: Mayoral Candidates, City of Lexington
brief_description: Come hear the candidates discuss how they will support the continued growth and vitality of our arts and culture community and address quality of life issues
description:
On November 6, 2018, Lexington residents will cast their vote for the city’s next mayor. On Monday, September 17, come hear the candidates discuss how they will support the continued growth and vitality of our arts and culture community and address quality of life issues.


This forum is free and open to the public, but seating is limited.


Who:

• LexArts (host)

• Ronnie Bastin, candidate for Mayor of Lexington

• Linda Gorton, candidate for Mayor of Lexington

• Lori Meadows, former executive director, Kentucky Arts Council, moderator


What:

• Mayoral candidates’ forum on the arts


When: 

• Monday, September 17

o 5:00pm Networking

o 5:30pm Forum

o 6:30pm Reception with light refreshments


Where:

• LexArts, 161 N. Mill Street, Lexington


How:

• Free and open to the public

• Registration is suggested (see link above) but not required

• Questions in writing from the audience will be collected and screened in advance via online survey (see link below) and during the event

• The forum will also be streamed live on Facebook


Why:

• To give voters an opportunity to learn the candidates’ views on the role of the arts in Lexington, how they would support the arts as mayor, and how the arts fit into their priorities for the city

• To give candidates an opportunity to hear voters’ hopes and concerns about the arts in Lexington


Click on tickets below or register here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/city-of-lexington-mayoral-forum-on-the-arts-tickets-49963550324


In advance of this forum you are invited to provide input through a survey on the issues candidates will be discussing. Follow the link to complete the survey: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/BJ2YH7H

title: Ppoacher ppoacher / Fighting Futures / Michael Tyree
brief_description: Caitlin Brothers of ppoacher ppoacher’s unique use of voice and earnestly goofy stage presence have left audiences wondering if the performer before them was an ethereal goblin, a feral roof dog, a long lost friend, a hillbilly Kate Bush impersonator, a banshee suffering an identity crisis, or a bag of feelings parading as a woman
description:
ppoacher ppoacher- Santa Fe, NM


https://facebook.com/ppoacherppoacher

https://matronrecords.com/ppoacherppoacher

https://ppoacherppoacher.bandcamp.com



Caitlin Brothers of ppoacher ppoacher’s unique use of voice and earnestly goofy stage presence have left audiences wondering if the performer before them was an ethereal goblin, a feral roof dog, a long lost friend, a hillbilly Kate Bush impersonator, a banshee suffering an identity crisis, or a bag of feelings parading as a woman...


Brothers’ distinct writing style is marked by congenial contrasts: passionate & playful, calculated & relaxed, approachable & quirky. The lyrics communicate a simultaneous existential dread and intoxicating thrill of living and loving, a practice in raw and shameless vulnerability. 


The recent addition of Nathan Smerage's contemporary old timer string stylings has made these tunes a bed of haunting and cyclical whimsy. Originally playing rock n roll guitar, this intensely talented instrumentalist found a new love in ragtime, fingerpicking and clawhammer banjo. All of these aspects dance together in his playing, creating a sense of warm timelessness and some just straight up catchy hooks. 


Residing in Santa Fe, NM by way of Fayetteville, AR, the influence of the land that made the woman making the music is palpable. Vocal Melodies expanding and contracting like a drive through the Sangre De Cristo Mountains, dipping howls and glottal stops like the churning of the Buffalo River, earthy grit of guttural tones like the red clay mud both lands harbor. 

One can easily hear the influence of various folk music traditions, pop sensibilities, old school country heartbreak, peppered with a feeling of moving through other worlds....primarily the emotional landscape; beauty transmuted through valleys of deep pain, peaks of ecstatic joy, soft rolling hills of serenity, jagged rock formations of rage, and the bizarre catharsis of the open hearted exploration of it all. The performer as vehicle, steering you through with spells of the tenor banjo, celtic harp, and mostly human voice.'


Fighting Futures- 


https://facebook.com/FightingFutures/


Local duo with a beautiful pair of voices harmonizing over tender folk arrangements with delightful pop sensibilities. 



Michael Tyree- 


https://www.michaeltyreemusic.com/about/


Michael Tyree is a guitarist and vocalist currently living in Lexington, KY. His solo work is primarily acoustic, and he sets himself apart from other singer/songwriters by sticking to darker themes and writing about cold, hard truths.

title: The Double Life of Véronique (presented by Rosa Goddard Fest)
brief_description: Kieślowski's The Double Life of Véronique seems to suggest that connection is everywhere
description:
SQecial Media is proud to present the second film in this year’s Rosa Goddard International Film Festival!


THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE (1991, dir. Krzysztof Kieślowski)

While La Notte presents a desperate search for connection, Kieślowski's The Double Life of Véronique seems to suggest that connection is everywhere. Two women, Weronika and Véronique (both played by the incredible Irène Jacob), unknown to each other, lead a very literal double life, with a nod to the collective unconscious. Mysterious and magical, this film could easily be seen as Kieślowski's prelude to the stunning Three Colours trilogy. Plus, there are puppets! 


Tickets cost $6 and will automatically enter attendees in a drawing for prizes before the film. Help us spread the word! The next and final film in the festival is IDA (September 26). All films will show on Wednesday nights at 7:15pm in the Kentucky Theater. 


Follow SQecial Media or the Rosa Goddard International Film Festival on Facebook for updates:

https://www.facebook.com/sqecialmedia

https://www.facebook.com/rosagoddardfilmfestival

title: Reading Roundtable for Melissa Carter: New Masters
brief_description: Join Institute 193 and the Feminist Art Project Kentucky for an informal discussion of texts on the themes presented in our current exhibition, Melissa Carter: New Masters
description:
Join Institute 193 and the Feminist Art Project Kentucky for an informal discussion of texts on the themes presented in our current exhibition, Melissa Carter: New Masters. We will cover classic texts like Linda Nochlin's 'Why Are There No Great Women Artists,' selections from publications by the Guerilla Girls, and excerpts from contemporary headlines like the recent open letter from artist-activist group We Are Not Surprised. All texts are available at the link below. This event is free and open to the public.

title: Curator's Talk with Trevor Martin
brief_description: Trevor Martin, Executive Director of Exhibitions at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, discusses the work in "Lake Effect", the exhibition he facilitated for Morlan Gallery.
description:
Facilitator's Talk with Trevor Martin | Thursday, September 20, 6 p.m., reception to follow


Lake Effect, facilitated by Trevor Martin '92, Executive Director of Exhibitions at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, features a quartet of contemporary artists connected to the city of Chicago. Through painting, sculpture, installation, and video, their works celebrate color, texture, and repetition to interrogate a range of material use and form. 


Morlan Gallery is open weekdays noon-5 p.m. and is located in the Mitchell Fine Arts Center on the historic campus of Transylvania University. Parking is free, ample and close! All events are free and open to the public.


Special Events and Hours

Closed October 15, 16 for Fall Break

title: I Was Here
brief_description: I Was Here is an artistic collaboration between poet Nikky Finney, Marjorie Guyon, and Patrick J Mitchell. The project is composed of twenty-one Ancestor Spirit Portraits
description:
I Was Here is an artistic collaboration between poet Nikky Finney, Marjorie Guyon, and Patrick J Mitchell. The project is composed of twenty-one Ancestor Spirit Portraits and centers on the public square, the physical heart of Lexington, Kentucky—Cheapside—which was one of the largest slave auction sites in the United States, but also references the Bight of Benin, the Igbo Landing on St. Simon's Island Georgia, the Broeck Race Course in Savannah, where the largest two-day sale of enslaved persons occurred, as well as other physical locations central to the long lucrative life of the transatlantic Middle Passage slave trade.


It is unknown how many hundreds of thousands of enslaved African people—men, women, and children were stripped from their families and sold as chattel. In 300 years of American history this horrific American truth has not been given the light and attention it deserves. This project seeks to begin the precious human work of looking at, looking behind, and looking ahead.


The Ancestor Spirit Portraits will be presented to the public for the first time on September 21 at the Carnegie Center at Gallery Hop. A community conversation, poetry reading, and artist’s talk is scheduled for September 22, 10 am – 2 pm, in hopes of planting a vision in the heart of Lexington, one that believes the spirit of the past can be redeemed and our future, as fellow citizens, more richly nurtured.


The artists, and the nine models whose faces and bodies are artistic representations of millions of unnamed ancestors, believe at this time in all our lives, on this small corner of the earth, it is necessary to illuminate, as evocatively and powerfully as they know how, the living presence of the real human beings who once stood waiting to be bought and sold and who faced unspeakable human crimes against their humanity. They believe it is never too late to remember and honor a piece of the human puzzle that makes us who we are. I Was Here honors that memory.


This artistic collaboration would not have been possible without support from Wells Fargo, Visit LEX, Kentucky Arts Council, Paul Holbrook, The King Library Press at The University of Kentucky, John Hays and Patrick Estill @ JacksonKelly, John Morris, Barry Darnell Burton, Bob Estes, Linda F. Vogel Kaplan, The Wills Gallery, Fine Art & Antiques, and Carnegie Center for Literacy & Learning.


For more information, visit i-was-here.org.

title: Short Plays
brief_description: We are pleased to present two newly-commissioned 20-minute plays based on Ralph Eugene Meatyard’s photographs
description:
Fri / Sept 21 / 6:30 – 8 pm

Sun / Oct 21 / 2 – 3 pm

Sat / Nov 17 / 2 – 3 pm 


FREE


We are pleased to present two newly-commissioned 20-minute plays based on Ralph Eugene Meatyard’s photographs. Each play will be performed once on each of the above dates.


HAPPY HOUSE, by Kara Lee Corthron

A house can hold just so much - furniture, folks, mysteries, memories, fire and fury - that sometimes it feels like it's about to burst. Other times, it might just - deflate. Come sit a spell and you decide about the feel of this here house.


Director: Peter Allen Stone

Stage Manager: John Thomas Priar

Cast: Harper: Katy Rucker (Freshman)

Isaiah: Carson Latham (Sophomore)

Sawyer: Maeada King (Junior)

Mother: Meredith Crutcher (local Lexington actor)




FALSE FACE, by Silas House

Jacob is a young man who has been traumatized by events both explosive and quiet. In FALSE FACE, he tells us his story--at least what he wants us to know of it--by exploring the nature of fear and the lack of nuanced thought in contemporary society. 


Director: Peter Allen Stone

Stage Manager: John Thomas Priar

Cast: Jacob: Josiah Correll (UK Theatre & Dance Graduate)

Mask 1/Mother: Maeada King (Junior)

Mask 2: Katy Rucker (Freshman)

brief_description: The second annual city-wide yard sale features notable artists and patrons around Lexington who will happily sell you their art, fashion, furniture, collectibles, and unique domestic items for a great cause
description:

The second annual city-wide yard sale features notable artists and patrons around Lexington who will happily sell you their art, fashion, furniture, collectibles, and unique domestic items for a great cause! Just imagine the deals and conversations waiting for you. A percentage of the day's sales will benefit the Art Museum. Maps and information available at finearts.uky.edu/art-museum.

title: Artist Talk and Performance with St. Lenox (Andrew Choi)
venues: Lucille Caudill Little Fine Arts Library
brief_description: Artist Talk with St. Lenox (Andrew Choi): Issues of Immigration in the Visual Album "Ten Hymns From My American Gothic"
description:
Artist Talk with St. Lenox (Andrew Choi): Issues of Immigration in the Visual Album 'Ten Hymns From My American Gothic' 


Performance to Follow at 7pm. Both events in the Niles Gallery in the Lucille Little Fine Arts Library.


Singer-songwriter, Andrew Choi, will discuss issues of immigration in his 2016 album Ten Hymns From My American Gothic, which was hailed as “a 21st century pop masterpiece” (PopMatters). The themes of this work were later expanded into visual concept album in June 2017 and elaborates on the aftermath of the presidential election, as well as other issues tackling a range of issues such as education, law, the immigrant experience, gun control, LGBT issues and American politics. Mr. Choi is also a Juilliard-trained violinist, received his Ph.D. in philosophy from Ohio State University, his law degree from NYU and is a practicing attorney in New York.


Co-Sponsored by the University of Kentucky Arts and Sciences Year of Migration, the School of Music, the Musicology and Ethnomusicology Division and the Longyear Endowment.

title: Message Theater presents: A Raisin in the Sun
brief_description: The Lyric Theatre & Cultural Arts Center and Message Theater are proud to present Lorraine Hansberry's 1959 classic, "A Raisin in the Sun"
description:
The Lyric Theatre & Cultural Arts Center and Message Theater are proud to present Lorraine Hansberry's 1959 classic, 'A Raisin in the Sun'.


60 years since its debut in 1959, 'A Raisin in the Sun' has continued to resound with generations of fans. Its timeless story of struggle and self-identity has a poignance and gravity that has influenced countless artists and adaptations over the years, and we are proud to add our names to this list.


There are no groups better than Message Theater to present this masterpiece, and no more significant location than The Lyric Theatre's historic stage for its setting. Don't miss this one of a kind performance!


'Message Theater's mission 'is to bridge the cultural gap in the Lexington Theater Community'. Lorraine Hansberry's epic play has a timeless, resounding message for all that that bridge connects to as she masterfully touches upon dreams, motherhood, love and life. Part of our goal in the community is to provide a venue for artists to express themselves and The Lyric Theatre is the epitome of that effort. We are so proud to have local talent as performers, set builders, prop masters and wardrobe apprentices as the community experiences theater in a grand way. It is a winning package gifted for the community.' 


-Patrick Mitchell, Director, Message Theater.


Join us for three performances:


Friday, September 28 - 7:30 pm

Saturday, September 29 - 7:30 pm

Sunday, September 30 - 3:00 pm


Learn more on the groups involved:

Message Theater

https://www.facebook.com/messagetheater59/


The Lyric Theatre & Cultural Arts Center:

www.lexingtonlyric.com


Thank you to our dedicated Sponsors:

Bluegrass Community Foundation

LexArts

Kentucky Arts Council

William L. Davis: Attorney at Law

Proscan Imaging

NIA Urban Ministries

Hamilton Saykaly Garbulinska Foundation

title: Neighborhood Engagement in Planting and Nurturing Urban Trees
venues: Lyric Theatre and Cultural Arts Center
brief_description: Learn about the dynamics of urban trees in the community from Senior Arboricultural Officer for the Borough of Hackney, London (England), Rupert Bentley Walls.
description:
Neighborhood Engagement in Planting and Nurturing Urban Trees


Rupert Bentley Walls will give this public seminar on his experience working in London and across the United Kingdom. He is an expert in tree planting, species selection, establishment and community engagement, local authority management structures, service provision, and understands how tree officers function. A description of Rupert's talk is as follows:

'Tree and site selection are frequently the primary emphases in community tree planting initiatives, but an often overlooked aspect of these initiatives is the process of engaging residents in recipient neighborhoods. Rupert Bentley Walls has spent his career in tree planting and tree care, creating and engaging in such relationships with residents of high need neighborhoods. Senior Arboricultural Officer for the Borough of Hackney, London (England), Rupert will discuss the barriers to, and share his successes in, expanding the tree canopy and creating resident tree advocates. '


The talk will go from 7pm - 8pm, but is preceeded by an hour (6pm - 7pm) of light refreshments and exhibitors from around the Lexington-Fayette area.


This event is sponsored by UK’s Department of Community & Leadership Development and the Urban Forestry Initiative

title: Art Talk with Claire Ashley and Jaclyn Mednicov
brief_description: "Lake Effect" artists Claire Ashley and Jaclyn Mednicov discuss their art practices, exuding with humor, wit and color.
description:
Art Talk with Claire Ashley and Jaclyn Mednicov | Thursday, Oct. 18, 6 p.m., Morlan Gallery,

followed by a closing reception from 7-8 p.m.


" Lake Effect ", facilitated by Trevor Martin '92, Executive Director of Exhibitions at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, features a quartet of contemporary artists connected to the city of Chicago: Claire Ashley, Susanna Coffey, Jaclyn Mednicov, and Maryam Taghavi. Through painting, sculpture, installation, and video, their works celebrate color, texture, and repetition to interrogate a range of material use and form. 


Morlan Gallery, open weekdays noon-5 p.m., is in the Mitchelle Fine Arts Center, located on the historic campus of Transylvania University. Parking is close, ample, and free! All events are free and open to the public.


Special Events and Hours

Curator’s Talk with Trevor Martin |Thursday, Sept. 20, 6 p.m., Morlan Gallery

title: Short Plays
brief_description: We are pleased to present two newly-commissioned 20-minute plays based on Ralph Eugene Meatyard’s photographs
description:
Fri / Sept 21 / 6:30 – 8 pm

Sun / Oct 21 / 2 – 3 pm

Sat / Nov 17 / 2 – 3 pm 


FREE


We are pleased to present two newly-commissioned 20-minute plays based on Ralph Eugene Meatyard’s photographs. Each play will be performed once on each of the above dates.


HAPPY HOUSE, by Kara Lee Corthron

A house can hold just so much - furniture, folks, mysteries, memories, fire and fury - that sometimes it feels like it's about to burst. Other times, it might just - deflate. Come sit a spell and you decide about the feel of this here house.


Director: Peter Allen Stone

Stage Manager: John Thomas Priar

Cast: Harper: Katy Rucker (Freshman)

Isaiah: Carson Latham (Sophomore)

Sawyer: Maeada King (Junior)

Mother: Meredith Crutcher (local Lexington actor)




FALSE FACE, by Silas House

Jacob is a young man who has been traumatized by events both explosive and quiet. In FALSE FACE, he tells us his story--at least what he wants us to know of it--by exploring the nature of fear and the lack of nuanced thought in contemporary society. 


Director: Peter Allen Stone

Stage Manager: John Thomas Priar

Cast: Jacob: Josiah Correll (UK Theatre & Dance Graduate)

Mask 1/Mother: Maeada King (Junior)

Mask 2: Katy Rucker (Freshman)

title: Festival del Dia de los Muertos // Day of The Dead Festival
brief_description: Experience the rich visual, musical, dance and culinary traditions of this holiday, celebrated in Mexico and parts of Central and South America
description: Experience the rich visual, musical, dance and culinary traditions of this holiday, celebrated in Mexico and parts of Central and South America. The Festival includes live music and dance performances, traditional food, hands-on crafts, art exhibits, a candlelight parade, and an exhibition of altars in the Old Episcopal Burying Ground. FREE event, 5-9pm, for the entire family

title: Eat/Art
brief_description: Join Museum staff on the second Wednesday of each month as we examine an artwork currently in storage
description: Join Museum staff on the second Wednesday of each month as we examine an artwork currently in storage. We'll discuss the artist, their career, and how the work fits into our permanent collection. Bring a brown bag lunch (no sloppy foods or liquids please).

title: Something Pretty - Lexington Gallery Hop Reception
brief_description: Artists Stephen Rolfe Powell, Tiffany Calvert, Angela Dufresne, Justin Favela, and HuiMeng Wang in an exhibition seeking to complicate and confront the the notion of "pretty"
description: Artists Stephen Rolfe Powell, Tiffany Calvert, Angela Dufresne, Justin Favela, and HuiMeng Wang in an exhibition seeking to complicate and confront the the notion of "pretty." Exhibition curated by Transylvania University assistant professor of art history, Emily Elizabeth Goodman, PhD.

title: Short Plays
brief_description: We are pleased to present two newly-commissioned 20-minute plays based on Ralph Eugene Meatyard’s photographs
description:
Fri / Sept 21 / 6:30 – 8 pm

Sun / Oct 21 / 2 – 3 pm

Sat / Nov 17 / 2 – 3 pm
